story_headline: GOP Sen. John Cornyn positive for COVID-19
story_copy: Senator John Cornyn tested positive for COVID-19 despite being vaccinated and boosted. In a tweet Monday, the Texas Republican said he‚Äôd been able to ‚Äúdodge‚Äù the virus for more than two years.After dodging it for 2+ years I‚Äôve tested positive for COVID-19. I‚Äôm fully vaccinated and boosted, and doing fine. While quarantining I‚Äôll continue to fight Chuck Schumer and Joe Manchin‚Äôs massive tax increase on working families remotely, consistent with CDC guidelines.‚Äî Senator John Cornyn (@JohnCornyn) August 1, 2022He then went on to note that his diagnosis could ‚Äúfurther complicate the math of floor votes‚Äù at the start of a busy week for the Senate. Senate Democrats this week hoped to pass their multi-billion dollar climate, tax and health care package which was announced by Senate Majority Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) and Sen. Joe Manchin¬†(D-W.Va.) on Wednesday. Republicans are expected to unanimously oppose the measure and the GOP has criticized the West Virginia Democrat for backing it.Schumer and Manchin are aiming to pass the package under reconciliation, an arcane budget rule that avoids the senate‚Äôs 60-vote threshold required for most bills. Democrats are also closely watching moderate Sen. Kyrsten Sinema (D-Ariz.) who has not yet announced a position on the reconciliation package.Sen.¬†Dick Durbin¬†(D-Ill.), the Senate majority whip,¬†announced on Thursday that he had tested positive for the virus and it is unclear when he will return to the Capitol.Moving forward, Cornyn said he will continue to work remotely while in isolation.
image_caption: WASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì MAY 10: Sen. John Cornyn (R-TX) speaks to reporters during a news conference after their weekly policy meeting with Senate Republicans, at the U.S. Capitol, May 10, 2016, in Washington, DC. (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)

story_headline: McKinney Fire in N. Calif. leaves two dead
story_copy: McKinney Fire in N. Calif. leaves two deadFlames from the McKinney Fire burn beyond firefighters in Klamath National Forest, Calif., on Sunday, July 31, 2022. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 6:35 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022Two people are dead and thousands more evacuated as firefighters battle California‚Äôs largest fire this season. Governor Gavin Newsom (D) declared a state of emergency Saturday as the McKinney Fire burning near the California-Oregon border continued to rage out of control. More than 55,000 acres have been charred since the flames broke out Friday. Crews found the bodies of two people in a burned-out vehicle Sunday morning.We were underneath this. In 22+ yrs of fire I‚Äôve never experienced anything like this fire behavior at night. It felt absolutely surreal and not just a little apocalyptic. https://t.co/oM6lfgQAVg‚Äî Dacia Grayber (@djgrayber) July 30, 2022As the weekend ended, the blaze was zero percent contained. Firefighters faced a long battle ahead as lightning and thunderstorms complicated efforts. Additionally, the flames raced through dry vegetation. Heavy smoke over the fire helped slow its growth Sunday, but also kept firefighting aircraft grounded. That‚Äôs according to the US Forest Service in a Sunday night update.Woke up while backcountry camping to 50+hot wind gusts, lightning, blowing ash, and this view through the trees (not a sunset!) on a high saddle approx 8mi SW of Mt. Ashland. Terrifying. Turns out it‚Äôs the #McKinneyFire pic.twitter.com/no55IAIL02‚Äî Dacia Grayber (@djgrayber) July 30, 2022‚ÄúThese conditions can be extremely dangerous for firefighters as winds can be erratic and extremely strong causing fire to spread in any direction,‚Äù forest service officials said in a news release.According to CNN meteorologist Haley Brink, more than 2 million people are under red flag warnings in parts of Northern California, Central Oregon, Eastern Washington, Montana, Eastern Wyoming, Western South Dakota and Northwestern Nebraska. More than 650 firefighters are on the scene and battling the blaze.
image_caption: Flames from the McKinney Fire burn beyond firefighters in Klamath National Forest, Calif., on Sunday, July 31, 2022. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

story_headline: Monkeypox cases in the US surpass 5K mark
story_copy: Monkeypox cases in the US surpass 5K markFILE ‚Äì This 1997 image provided by U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the right arm and torso of a patient, whose skin displayed a number of lesions due to what had been an active case of monkeypox. (CDC via AP, File)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 6:05 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022The CDC said there are now more than 5,000 cases of Monkeypox in the United States. The new CDC data showed New York State has more than 1,000 cases of Monkeypox, while California has roughly 700 cases and Illinois has around 400 cases. Monkeypox has been reportedly detected in all 50 states except Montana, Vermont and Wyoming. The US identified the first Monkeypox case in May, as spread has continued to increase which has prompted health officials to request more vaccines.NEW: US surpasses 5,000 cases of monkeypox.CDC now lists Indiana with 49 cases, including two pediatric cases announced by state health officials.@WISH_TV pic.twitter.com/z0WcajRZTI‚Äî Brady Gibson (@bradygibson) July 29, 2022‚ÄúThe mistakes we saw during the COVID-19 pandemic are already being repeated,‚Äù said Dr. Boghuma Kabisen Titanji, an assistant professor of medicine at Emory University.New York City Mayor Eric Adams asserted that his officials will ‚Äúexpand outreach and access to vaccines‚Äù while informing that nearly 150,000 New Yorkers may currently be at risk of Monkeypox exposure. Adams called it a ‚Äúgrowing outbreak‚Äù as New York Governor Kathy Hochul (D) issued an order declaring the Monkeypox virus a state disaster emergency. According to the CDC, America‚Äôs financial hub has recorded 1,345 Monkeypox cases as Hochul pointed out New York accounted for one in four Monkeypox cases in the US.‚ÄúThis is an outbreak that can be stopped,‚Äù WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated. ‚ÄúThe best way to do that is to reduce the risk of exposure.‚ÄùSteps to prevent #monkeypox: üö´ Avoid close, skin-to-skin contact w/ people who have a rash that looks like monkeypox. üö´ Do not handle or touch bedding, towels, or clothing of a person w/ monkeypox. ‚úîÔ∏è Wash hands often. https://t.co/ppvFSRP8BT pic.twitter.com/sgZLXmA8tK‚Äî CDC (@CDCgov) July 29, 2022Read CDC‚Äôs updated recommendations for people with #monkeypox. If you have monkeypox, isolate until your rash has fully healed. If you need to go out, cover your rash, wear a well-fitting mask, and avoid public transportation. Learn more: https://t.co/q2CNaAY2mx. pic.twitter.com/UFCI7gJKri‚Äî CDC (@CDCgov) August 1, 2022However, as Monkeypox vaccines were originally intended for smallpox more data is said to be needed to confirm its real effectiveness.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì This 1997 image provided by U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the right arm and torso of a patient, whose skin displayed a number of lesions due to what had been an active case of monkeypox. (CDC via AP, File)

story_headline: WH: Pelosi ‚Äòhas the right‚Äô to visit Taiwan amid China warning
story_copy: WH: Pelosi ‚Äòhas the right‚Äô to visit Taiwan amid China warningNational Security Council spokesman John Kirby listens to a question during a briefing at the White House, Monday, Aug. 1, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 3:20 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022White House National Security Council Spokesperson John Kirby said Nancy Pelosi has the right to visit Taiwan despite warnings by China. Kirby told reporters on Monday, the Biden administration is fully committed to the One China Policy negotiated by former President Jimmy Carter.China‚Äôs actions could include firing missiles near Taiwan, large-scale air or naval activities, or further ‚Äúspurious legal claims‚Äù such as Beijing‚Äôs assertion that the Taiwan Strait is not an international waterway, Kirby told reporters.‚ÄúWe will not take the bait or engage in saber rattling,‚Äù Kirby voiced. ‚ÄúAt the same time, we will not be intimidated.‚Äù¬†John Kirby: ‚ÄúWe do not support Taiwan independence‚Äù pic.twitter.com/7NaT3RWbME‚Äî Benny Johnson (@bennyjohnson) August 1, 2022Kirby said that nothing about Pelosi‚Äôs possible trip changed US policy toward Taiwan and that Beijing was well aware that the division in powers within the US government meant Pelosi would make her own decisions about the visit.‚ÄúThe speaker has the right to visit Taiwan,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúA speaker of the House has visited Taiwan before without incident as have many members of Congress, including this year,‚Äù he stated.The Chinese PLA has just posted a new video ahead of #Pelosi's possible visit to #Taiwan.#China pic.twitter.com/rj5MLvYR9a‚Äî ÿÆÿßŸÑÿØ ÿßÿ≥ŸÉŸäŸÅ (@khalediskef) August 1, 2022The White House spokesperson said Pelosi‚Äôs decision on the Taiwan visit is not informed by China‚Äôs position. The Taiwanese media claimed Pelosi will visit the island nations this week although her travel plans still remain ambiguous.
image_caption: National Security Council spokesman John Kirby listens to a question during a briefing at the White House, Monday, Aug. 1, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)

story_headline: Minneapolis Fed Pres.: Biden played politics of economy badly
story_copy: Minneapolis Fed Pres.: Biden played politics of economy badlyOAN NewsroomUPDATED 2:20 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022FILE PHOTO: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari poses during an interview with Reuters in his office at the bank‚Äôs headquarters in Minneapolis, Minnesota, U.S., January 10, 2020. REUTERS/ Ann SaphirPresident of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis Neel Kashkari said Democrats are responsible for economic problems facing the US. In an interview Sunday, Kashkari pointed out that Biden‚Äôs officials falsely denied that inflation would get out of hand and now they are trying to change the definition of a recession.‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt wait to hear from the media that they‚Äôre in a recession,‚Äù said Kashkari. ‚ÄúMost peoples pay checks are not going as far as it used to and that is true. They‚Äôre going to think this is a recession, they‚Äôre going to think this is a bad economy and they‚Äôre hold the party in power accountable. This administration I think has consistently played politics of the economy badly.‚Äù"We would love it if we can transition to a sustainable economy without tipping the economy into recession. There's not a great record of doing that."Neel Kashkari, Minneapolis Fed Bank president, said we are "a long way away" from an economy that is back at 2% inflation. pic.twitter.com/F8Mb7Bm6Ke‚Äî Face The Nation (@FaceTheNation) August 1, 2022The central banker said administration officials should not have done that and they should have admitted responsibility instead. He added that the US economy is not doing well.‚ÄúFirst in denying that inflation was going to happen, denying that it was going to stick around and now getting into this absurd definitional argument about whether we are in a recession or not,‚Äù he stated.Kashkari went on to say that the fed‚Äôs goal is to get inflation to below two percent however they can.
image_caption: FILE PHOTO: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari poses during an interview with Reuters in his office at the bank‚Äôs headquarters in Minneapolis, Minnesota, U.S., January 10, 2020. REUTERS/ Ann Saphir

story_headline: Rep. Comer: Feds knew of Hunter Biden‚Äôs dealings all along
story_copy: Rep. Comer: Feds knew of Hunter Biden‚Äôs dealings all alongHouse Oversight Committee Ranking Member Rep. James Comer Jr., R-Ky., listens during a hearing on the Washington Commanders‚Äô workplace conduct, Wednesday, June 22, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 1:20 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022Congressman James Comer (R-Ky.) said he‚Äôs looking into Hunter Biden‚Äôs questionable foreign dealings. In a recent interview, the Kentucky Congressman said several banks flagged at least 150 financial transactions involving Hunter as suspicious.‚ÄúText messages show that Hunter Biden was aware of these SARs and took steps to avoid detection in his financial dealings,‚Äù Comer noted.The GOP lawmaker explained this only happens when the bank has solid reasons to believe their client is involved in criminal activity. He added, the Biden administration may be running a cover-up for Hunter.House Oversight Committee Republicans have been investigating the scandal-scarred first son‚Äôs domestic and foreign business relationships as well as any effort to benefit from his father. According to the GOP members, the SARs raise ‚Äúserious questions about what these transactions were for and whether money was transferred to the Biden family from America‚Äôs adversaries.‚Äùüö®NEWüö®@RepJamesComer presses Hunter Biden‚Äôs financial advisor, Edward Prewitt, for information about the Biden family‚Äôs foreign business deals that have triggered suspicious activity reports.The American people deserve to know. https://t.co/UwTOzV2uyK‚Äî Oversight Committee Republicans (@GOPoversight) July 27, 2022‚ÄúCommittee Republicans are committed to following Hunter Biden‚Äôs money trail consisting of many complex, international transactions worth millions of dollars,‚Äù stated Comer. ‚ÄúThe American people deserve to know the President‚Äôs connections to his son‚Äôs business deals, which have occurred at the expense of American interests and may represent a national security threat.‚ÄùAccording to the Kentucky Congressman, Edward Prewitt and his firm managed the accounts of the first son‚Äôs businesses, including Owasco PC, Owasco LLC, Skaneateles and Rosemont Seneca Advisors. They also managed a Hudson West, which has reprotedly been used in transferring millions of dollars to Hunter and James Biden from CEFC. This company has been said to be ‚Äúeffectively an arm of the Chinese government.‚ÄùWATCH: @RepJamesComer shares new details on the Biden Crime Family:‚ÄúA suspicious activity report is when the bank notifies the federal government that they have a strong suspicion of criminal activity by their client‚Ä¶Hunter Biden received at least 150 of these.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/KnxFXhs5Xe‚Äî House Republicans (@HouseGOP) July 30, 2022‚ÄúYou have an obligation to the country to take these allegations seriously, immediately investigate and take steps to institute fixes to these and other matters before you,‚Äù the senator voiced to the Biden administration officials.‚ÄãComer also said his Oversight Committee is focused on investigating Hunter Biden. The probe is expected to intensify if Republicans take back the House in November.
image_caption: House Oversight Committee Ranking Member Rep. James Comer Jr., R-Ky., listens during a hearing on the Washington Commanders‚Äô workplace conduct, Wednesday, June 22, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin)

story_headline: Dutch farmer problems could be coming to America
story_copy: Dutch farmer problems could be coming to AmericaProtesting farmers block a drawbridge at locks in the Princess Margriet canal, preventing all ship traffic from passing in Gaarkeuken, northern Netherlands, Monday, July 4, 2022. (AP Photo/Peter Dejong)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 12:10 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022The farmer protests have continued in the Netherlands and many are saying Americans should start paying more attention. As tensions rise between farmers and the government in the country, the impacts are being felt across the globe.‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what could be more essential to communism than that,‚Äù said Eva Vlaardingerbroek, a legal philosopher. ‚ÄúSo, you know, it‚Äôs communism and I‚Äôm saying it‚Äôs being done on a global scale because this is part of a bigger agenda than just the agenda of the Dutch government.‚ÄùThis week, farmers continued to fight the government‚Äôs plans to cut nitrogen emissions by restricting livestock and fertilizer use so heavily that it will send many farms out of business. These plans come after a court ruled the initial emissions plan violated EU laws protecting endangered plants and animals, which caused the Dutch government to target their own farmers.‚ÄúYes it‚Äôs true that the Dutch government wants the farmers land,‚Äù the philosopher voiced. ‚ÄúFor one reason is to house new immigrants, but this is also because they are following an agenda called the 2030 agenda. These are restrictions and climate regulations that are imposed all over the world. We‚Äôre being hit hardest right now. We might be the first ones, but it‚Äôs very important for other people to know they could be coming to you next.‚ÄùThe 2030 plan is an agenda put forth by the United Nations, supposedly to improve many aspects of global peace. One aspect of this agenda is to cut emissions by any means necessary which will cause backlash among those affected.‚ÄúWe already see now that in Italy farmers have gone out on the street as well,‚Äù she stated. ‚ÄúIn Poland farmers are going out. So it‚Äôs spilling over which is a really good sign because like I said these restrictions are going to be very relevant for everyone because obviously it‚Äôs a global agenda.‚ÄùAs I drive through the Netherland countryside, I see massive hay stacks of loose hay piled up adjacent to highways. It must have been part of the plan, because with a quick tractor push and lighter, the highways are ablaze. Farmers are not going gently. pic.twitter.com/0LaiMoYNYQ‚Äî Keean Bexte üá≥üá± (@TheRealKeean) July 7, 2022The agenda was recently implemented in Sri Lanka where the government banned chemical fertilizers which caused a food shortage and economic crisis to erupt across the country. This resulted in the ouster of the government. With so many other countries already experiencing similar restrictions some said it is only a matter of time before American farmers start becoming affected.If enacted in America, the restrictions would likely force mass culling of livestock, use of synthetic fertilizers and end with many farmers losing their business and land all together. There are no plans to go as far as The Netherlands in the US currently, but Democrats have recently passed an anti-energy spending spree which gives over $300 billion to so-called green energy technologies. They claim these technologies will reduce emissions 40 percent by 2030. This will line up with the UN‚Äôs agenda target date.
image_caption: Protesting farmers block a drawbridge at locks in the Princess Margriet canal, preventing all ship traffic from passing in Gaarkeuken, northern Netherlands, Monday, July 4, 2022. (AP Photo/Peter Dejong)

story_headline: Poll: GOP to get 230 House seats in Nov. midterms
story_copy: Poll: GOP to get 230 House seats in Nov. midtermsA woman votes in the presidential primary election at the the Summit View Church of the Nazarene in Kansas City, Mo., on March 10, 2020.Charlie Riedel / AP fileOAN NewsroomUPDATED 6:50 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022A new poll claims Republicans would get a slight advantage over Democrats in the House of Representatives after this year‚Äôs midterms. According to CBS News‚Äô ‚Äúbattleground tracker,‚Äù the GOP would secure 230 seats in the House this November while Democrats would hold 205 seats. The poll found Republicans would get 12 seats more than the 218 required to control the lower chamber.Meanwhile, a rising number of voters are leaning Republican in upcoming midterms due to economic recession, runaway inflation and other Democrat policy failures. Republicans are expecting a much larger red wave that is predicted by this poll.‚ÄúWell, they are afraid of us,‚Äù stated Kari Lake, (R) Arizona gubernatorial candidate. ‚ÄúThey thought that when they stole that election in 2020 they made Donald Trump, the America First movement and all the patriots go away. That we would just crawl off and never return, but we‚Äôre emboldened. We‚Äôre not gonna back down and we‚Äôre gonna fight.‚Äù¬†The CBS poll also found enthusiasm among Democrat voters is extremely low and they are less likely to show up to vote than Republicans.
image_caption: A woman votes in the presidential primary election at the the Summit View Church of the Nazarene in Kansas City, Mo., on March 10, 2020.Charlie Riedel / AP file

story_headline: White House slammed for weak response to China‚Äôs threat over Pelosi‚Äôs possible Taiwan visit
story_copy: White House slammed for weak response to China‚Äôs threat over Pelosi‚Äôs possible Taiwan visitIn this photo provided by Ministry of Communications and Information, Singapore, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, left, and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong shake hands at the Istana Presidential Palace in Singapore, Monday, Aug. 1, 2022. Pelosi arrived in Singapore early Monday, kicking off her Asian tour as questions swirled over a possible stop in Taiwan that has fueled tension with Beijing. (Ministry of Communications and Information, Singapore via AP)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 11:11 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, August 1, 2022The White House offered a feeble response to China‚Äôs threat of shooting down House Speaker Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs (D-Calif.) flight to Taiwan.On Friday, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre seemingly undermined the threat. She suggested that since China‚Äôs statement related to Pelosi‚Äôs travel schedule, she can not speak on it because it is ‚Äúhypothetical.‚ÄùUnbelievable: Karine Jean-Pierre says the White House won't respond to Chinese state media threats to shoot down Nancy Pelosi's plane should she visit Taiwan."We're just not going to speak on her schedule."Abject, embarrassing weakness. pic.twitter.com/4Biw7DsqBr‚Äî John Cooper (@thejcoop) July 29, 2022¬†While Pelosi‚Äôs trip does not officially include Taiwan, China‚Äôs Hu Xijin, who serves as the country‚Äôs propagandist, said China would gun down Pelosi‚Äôs plane. On Twitter, many former White House officials expressed their dismay over the statement. They called it a shame and an embarrassing display of the administration‚Äôs weakness.Pelosi‚Äôs trip to Asia departed on Sunday. It will include stops to Japan, South Korea, Malaysia and Singapore. She is expected to speak on legislative matters.
image_caption: In this photo provided by Ministry of Communications and Information, Singapore, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, left, and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong shake hands at the Istana Presidential Palace in Singapore, Monday, Aug. 1, 2022. Pelosi arrived in Singapore early Monday, kicking off her Asian tour as questions swirled over a possible stop in Taiwan that has fueled tension with Beijing. (Ministry of Communications and Information, Singapore via AP)

story_headline: Pelosi becomes first House Speaker in 25 years to visit Taiwan
story_copy: Pelosi becomes first House Speaker in 25 years to visit TaiwanIn this photo released by the Taiwan Ministry of Foreign Affairs, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, center, walks with Taiwan‚Äôs Foreign Minister Joseph Wu, left, as she arrives in Taipei, Taiwan, Tuesday, Aug. 2, 2022. Pelosi arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday night despite threats from Beijing of serious consequences, becoming the highest-ranking American official to visit the self-ruled island claimed by China in 25 years. ( Taiwan Ministry of Foreign Affairs via AP)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 11:40 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) safely landed in Taipei, Taiwan. She arrived Tuesday after much back and forth over whether she would heed threats from Mainland China.In a statement released after she landed, Pelosi said the congressional delegation‚Äôs visit to Taiwan honors America‚Äôs unwavering commitment to supporting Taiwan‚Äôs vibrant democracy. She added, her discussions with leadership there will focus on reaffirming support and promoting shared interests, including a free and open Indo-Pacific region.Pelosi said America‚Äôs solidarity with the 23 million people of Taiwan is more important today than ever as the world faces a choice between autocracy and democracy.Our visit is one of several Congressional delegations to Taiwan ‚Äì and it in no way contradicts longstanding United States policy, guided by the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, U.S.-China Joint Communiques and the Six Assurances.‚Äî Nancy Pelosi (@SpeakerPelosi) August 2, 2022Meanwhile, 26 Republicans senators are standing behind Pelosi‚Äôs decision to visit Taiwan. The group, including Sens. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), Joni Ernst (R-Iowa ) and John Thune (R-S.D.) released a joint statement on the trip Tuesday. They noted that this trip is in line with the One-China policy the US remains committed to because for decades members of Congress, including previous Speakers of the House, have traveled to.People walk past a billboard welcoming U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, in Taipei, Taiwan, Tuesday, Aug 2, 2022. U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was believed headed for Taiwan on Tuesday on a visit that could significantly escalate tensions with Beijing, which claims the self-ruled island as its own territory. (AP Photo/Chiang Ying-ying)Specifically, Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-Alaska) noted, ‚Äúat the end of the day, you do not want the Chinese Communist Party dictating to senior American leaders where they can and cannot travel.‚Äù‚ÄúMy view, and I think the view of a number of senators, is that we should close ranks now and not let the Chinese Communist Party try to drive wedges between American elected officials or the White House on whether or not she should be there,‚Äù stated Sullivan. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs there. We‚Äôre supporting the trip and we‚Äôre closing ranks behind her.‚ÄùSen. Rick Scott (R-Fla.) was notably not among the signatories, but has showed support on Twitter. He said the threats made by the Chinese ambassador to the US are unacceptable. The Florida lawmaker noted, ‚Äúany escalation will be the fault of Communist China alone, but the U.S. will not ignore aggression.‚Äù
image_caption: In this photo released by the Taiwan Ministry of Foreign Affairs, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, center, walks with Taiwan‚Äôs Foreign Minister Joseph Wu, left, as she arrives in Taipei, Taiwan, Tuesday, Aug. 2, 2022. Pelosi arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday night despite threats from Beijing of serious consequences, becoming the highest-ranking American official to visit the self-ruled island claimed by China in 25 years. ( Taiwan Ministry of Foreign Affairs via AP)

story_headline: Betsy DeVos demands abolition of Dept. of Education
story_copy: Betsy DeVos demands abolition of Dept. of EducationWASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì MARCH 28: U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos testifies during a Senate Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Subcommittee discussing proposed budget estimates and justification for FY2020 for the Education Department on March 28, 2019 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Zach Gibson/Getty Images)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 1:04 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022Former Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, once again, called for the abolition of the department she once headed. When she spoke to Breitbart on Monday, she said that anybody who is serious about reducing the size of the federal government should get on board with cutting the Education Department. DeVos suggested this idea must be a central tenet of the Republican party platform.According to the former Education Secretary, the bureaucracy does what it can to work against the interests of the people. She claimed the department was started in the 70s due to a corrupt political bargain. Since then, she feels it has only been used to increase the power of teachers‚Äô unions and other self-interested groups.‚ÄúI just think about the experience in the Department of Education and how formidable the bureaucracy is,‚Äù explained DeVos. ‚ÄúAnd how difficult it is to advance policy in an environment where the vast majority of the individuals are actually working against you.‚Äù¬†DeVos went on to say that she wants to see education policy returned to the United States.
image_caption: WASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì MARCH 28: U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos testifies during a Senate Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Subcommittee discussing proposed budget estimates and justification for FY2020 for the Education Department on March 28, 2019 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Zach Gibson/Getty Images)

story_headline: Guy Reffitt sentenced to 7 years despite not entering Capitol Building
story_copy: Guy Reffitt sentenced to 7 years despite not entering Capitol BuildingNicole Reffitt talks to reporters outside of federal court in Washington, Tuesday, March 8, 2022. Her husband is Guy Wesley Reffitt, a Texas man who was convicted on Tuesday of storming the U.S. Capitol with a holstered handgun, interfering with police officers who were guarding the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and for obstructing justice by threatening his two teenage children if they reported him to law enforcement after the Capitol attack. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 2:20 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022Texas resident Guy Reffitt is sentenced to seven years for his part in the US Capitol protest on January 6, which is the longest sentence for a defendant yet. He was sentenced to multiple years behind bars, despite never once entering the Capitol Building.Back in March, he was convicted of carrying a gun on US Capitol grounds. Prosecutors demanded a 15-year sentence and to designate Reffitt as a terrorist, but the judge refused while citing he never unholstered his firearm.Reffitt‚Äôs wife, Nicole, said that she wasn‚Äôt surprised and asserted that her husband is just the start of political persecution.‚ÄúIf we allow our country to keep being driven into the ground by the corrupt, evil politicians here in this city, then one day at your kitchen table the FBI is going to come in and tell you that you stood up at the school board meeting and you are now a domestic terrorist,‚Äù she told the media. ‚ÄúSo wake up, America. This isn‚Äôt just about Guy Wesley Reffitt. This isn‚Äôt about just 1/6. This is about our liberties being stomped on.‚ÄùReffitt was turned in by his son, who accused his father of threatening him and his sister if they went to the police, which the jury convicted Reffitt of doing as well. His has said he absolutely agrees with the verdict.
image_caption: Nicole Reffitt talks to reporters outside of federal court in Washington, Tuesday, March 8, 2022. Her husband is Guy Wesley Reffitt, a Texas man who was convicted on Tuesday of storming the U.S. Capitol with a holstered handgun, interfering with police officers who were guarding the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and for obstructing justice by threatening his two teenage children if they reported him to law enforcement after the Capitol attack. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: Biden selects FEMA official to lead monkeypox response team
story_copy: Biden selects FEMA official to lead monkeypox response teamFILE ‚Äì Committee chairman Rep. Bennie Thompson, D-Miss., gives opening remarks at the Capitol in Washington, June 9, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 10:17 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022President Joe Biden has tapped a FEMA official to lead his administration‚Äôs monkeypox response team amid states of emergency across the country. On Tuesday, the White House named regional coordinator Robert Fenton as the response team‚Äôs coordinator and CDC official Dr. Demetre Daskalakis as deputy coordinator.Fenton and Dr. Daskalakis, an expert on health issues affecting the LGBTQ community, will be tasked with spearheading strategy to address the ongoing outbreak. This as comes as California, Illinois and New York have all declared states of emergency as cases rise. The White House has not said if the administration plans to declare a health emergency on a national scale.‚ÄúSo when it comes to a public health emergency, that is a decision that that is made by Secretary Becerra,‚Äù stated White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre. ‚ÄúThat is not made by the president. But, as you know, we are considering every policy option to help end this outbreak that is urgent and that is important to us. But again, that is up to Secretary Sarah to make that decision.‚Äù¬†Three House Democrats recently requesed a review of the federal government‚Äôs response to monkeypox. Representatives Bennie Thompson (D-Miss.), Richie Torres (D-N.Y.) and Val Demings (D-Fla.) wrote a letter to the Government Accountability Office (GAO) on Monday.The three Democrats asked the agency to conduct a review of the response due to concerns about the virus spreading over the past two months because of delays in procuring tests as well as vaccines. The letter also included a request for the GAO to figure out if any agencies learned anything from the response of the COVID-19 pandemic.House Homeland Security Chair @BennieGThompson, @valdemings, and I are calling on @USGAO to investigate the federal government‚Äôs delayed response to the Monkeypox outbreak. The US should spare no effort to secure the homeland from infectious disease. https://t.co/plEonSBXBm‚Äî Ritchie Torres (@RitchieTorres) August 2, 2022According the CDC, there are now more than 5,000 cases of monkeypox in the US. The virus has been detected in 47 states with Montana, Vermont and Wyoming being the only three with zero cases reported. California and New York are leading in case numbers, while Illinois trails behind them in third.President Joe Biden is receiving pressure from Democrat House lawmakers to declare a public health emergency amid the rising number in cases across the country. In the meantime, Fenton and Dr. Daskalakis will be working on increasing the availability of testing and vaccines.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Committee chairman Rep. Bennie Thompson, D-Miss., gives opening remarks at the Capitol in Washington, June 9, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)

story_headline: Sen. McConnell addresses Ky. flooding on Senate floor
story_copy: Sen. McConnell addresses Ky. flooding on Senate floorThis July 28, 2022 photo provided by Appalshop shows the flooded Appalshop building in Whitesburg, Ky. The cultural center known for chronicling Appalachian life is cleaning up and assessing its losses. Like much of its stricken region, Appalshop has been swamped by historic flooding. The water inundated downtown Whitesburg in southeastern Kentucky, causing extensive damage to the renowned repository of Appalachian history and culture. (Appalshop via AP)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 11:05 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022Extreme flooding wreaked havoc in Kentucky, prompting a response from the state‚Äôs top Republican in Congress. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R- Ky.) delivered updates on the ongoing tragedy in his home state on the Senate floor on Monday.McConnell said the horrible tragedy is far from over and mentioned that records are being broken. He highlighted the fact that some counties in Kentucky are completely submerged in water. So far, the flooding has ravaged 13 counties.‚ÄúIn Jackson, waters reached 43 and a half feet high breaking an 83 year old record,‚Äù explained the senator. ‚ÄúDrone footage shows whole towns completely submerged. Roadways have turned into rivers. Rising waters have reached rooftops.‚ÄùThe National Guard has been called in to assist first responders for the declared state of emergency.‚ÄúOur heroic first responders, including the National Guard from Kentucky and surrounding states, are working overtime to find and recover stranded residents.‚Äù McConnell explained. ‚ÄúThey rescued more than 1,400 individuals in floodwaters hill. Nearly half of the rescues were by air.‚ÄùSome believe the recovery time could take several months and possibly even years. However, the Republican is confident in the resiliency of Kentuckians and believes the state will bounce back.More heavy rainfall is expected to hit Kentucky throughout the week.
image_caption: This July 28, 2022 photo provided by Appalshop shows the flooded Appalshop building in Whitesburg, Ky. The cultural center known for chronicling Appalachian life is cleaning up and assessing its losses. Like much of its stricken region, Appalshop has been swamped by historic flooding. The water inundated downtown Whitesburg in southeastern Kentucky, causing extensive damage to the renowned repository of Appalachian history and culture. (Appalshop via AP)

story_headline: Biden announces death of Al-Qaeda leader in Kabul
story_copy: Biden announces death of Al-Qaeda leader in KabulFILE ‚Äì In this 1998 file photo made available on March 19, 2004, Ayman al-Zawahri poses for a photograph in Khost, Afghanistan. Al-Zawahri, the top al-Qaida leader, was killed by the U.S. over the weekend in Afghanistan. President Joe Biden is scheduled to speak about the operation on Monday night, Aug. 1, 2022, from the White House in Washington. (AP Photo/Mazhar Ali Khan, File)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 6:32 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022The White House announced the death of a prominent figure in Al-Qaeda. President Joe Biden confimred the successful killing of terrorist leader Ayman Al-Zawahiri. In a Monday press conference, the President said Zawahiri was killed by a drone strike over the weekend in the Afghan capitol of Kabul.‚ÄúAfter relentlessly seeking Zawahri for years under Presidents Bush, Obama and Trump, our Intelligence Community located Zawahri earlier this year,‚Äù Biden stated. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd moved to downtown Kabul to reunite with members of his immediate family. After carefully considering clear and convincing evidence of his location, I authorized a precision strike that would remove him from the battlefield once and for all. This mission was carefully planned, rigorously minimized the risk of harm to other civilians.‚ÄùZawahiri played a prominent role in the organization by acting as Osama Bin Laden‚Äôs second-in-command before taking over as their leader after the death of Bin Laden in 2011. He was also reportedly involved in the planning of the September 11 attack on the World Trade Center as well as bombings at two US embassies in Africa that claimed the lives of 224 people.‚ÄúHe was deeply involved in the planning of 9/11,‚Äù said Biden. ‚ÄúOne of the most responsible for the attacks and murdered 2,977 people on American soil. For decades, he was the mastermind behind attacks against Americans, including the bombing of the USS Cole in 2000 which killed 17 American sailors and wounded dozens more. He played a key role in the bombing of the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing 224 and wounding over 4,500 others.‚ÄùBiden then went on to say that he will be continuing to address threats from the organization despite the death of Zawahiri.‚ÄúMy administration will continue to vigilantly monitor and address threats from Al-Qaeda, no matter where they emanate from,‚Äù he noted. ‚ÄúAs Commander-in-Chief, it is my solemn responsibility to make America safe in a dangerous world. The United States did not seek this war against terror. It came to us. We answered with the same principles of resolve that have shaped us for generation upon generation, to protect the innocent, defend liberty and we keep the light of freedom burning a beacon for the rest of the entire world.‚ÄùToday, and every day, I am grateful to the superb patriots who serve in the United States intelligence and counterterrorism community.It is thanks to their extraordinary persistence and skill that this operation was a success ‚Äì they have made us all safer. pic.twitter.com/OUARNt1Kdv‚Äî President Biden (@POTUS) August 2, 2022The operation marked the first publicly announced CIA strike in Afghanistan since¬† Biden‚Äôs botched withdrawal of US forces last year. Zawahiri‚Äôs death comes as a heavy blow to international terrorism and it may reduce competition between the Taliban and Al-Qaeda in the Afghan powerplay.Senior Taliban figures were reportedly aware of Zawahiri‚Äôs presence in the area. They even took steps to conceal his presence after Saturday‚Äôs successful strike by restricting access to the safe house and rapidly relocating members of his family, including his daughter and her children who were intentionally not targeted during the strike and remained unharmed. The US did not alert Taliban officials ahead of Saturday‚Äôs strike.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì In this 1998 file photo made available on March 19, 2004, Ayman al-Zawahri poses for a photograph in Khost, Afghanistan. Al-Zawahri, the top al-Qaida leader, was killed by the U.S. over the weekend in Afghanistan. President Joe Biden is scheduled to speak about the operation on Monday night, Aug. 1, 2022, from the White House in Washington. (AP Photo/Mazhar Ali Khan, File)

story_headline: Bill Clinton: A Recession is Two Quarters of Negative Growth
story_copy: Bill Clinton: A Recession is Two Quarters of Negative GrowthA man shops at a supermarket on Wednesday, July 27, 2022, in New York. The U.S. economy shrank from April through June for a second straight quarter, contracting at a 0.9% annual pace and raising fears that the nation may be approaching a recession. (AP Photo/Andres Kudacki)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 7:54 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022A video of former President Bill Clinton defining a recession was highlighted by GOP lawmakers as the Biden administration attempts to redefine the term. Sen. Ted Cruz (R- Texas) posted the video of Clinton on Saturday with the comment ‚ÄùBill Clinton was right.‚ÄùBill Clinton was right. https://t.co/bZtObFlJji‚Äî Ted Cruz (@tedcruz) July 31, 2022The video from December 2000 shows the former President defining recession by its common definition after being asked about his fears of an oncoming recession. This quote resurged decades later as the Biden administration refused to describe the current state of the economy as being in a recession. Despite last weeks GDP report, which showed a second consecutive quarter of negative growth, the administration has attempted to redefine the qualifications needed for a recession.Meanwhile, a video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D- Calif) talking about the ‚Äútechnical definition of recession‚Äù has reemerged from July 2008. The video, which resurfaced after last weeks GDP report release, also shows the top Democrat agreeing two quarters of negative growth does, in fact, suggest there is a recession. Pelosi is now distancing herself from her previous definition and is trying to downplay the current state of the economy under President Biden.Nancy Pelosi in July 2008: The ‚Äútechnical definition of recession‚Äù is two quarters of negative growth pic.twitter.com/JNhzNbgTXa‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 29, 2022¬†The 45th President also chimed in on the matter while taking to his social media app, Truth Social. Donald Trump suggested the Democrat proposed tax increase would violate Biden‚Äôs promises. He noted, ‚ÄúBig Tax increase for all Americans being pushed by Democrats. This is the opposite of the Biden pledge!‚ÄùHis statement comes after a senatorial committee on taxation discovered that taxes would rise for people making $30,000 and up per year. This comes despite Biden‚Äôs previous promises that taxes would only increase for top earners. Trump believes that the tax increase is coming amid an economic recession and that an increase would lead US manufactures to flee the country, which would result in Americans suffering even more.
image_caption: A man shops at a supermarket on Wednesday, July 27, 2022, in New York. The U.S. economy shrank from April through June for a second straight quarter, contracting at a 0.9% annual pace and raising fears that the nation may be approaching a recession. (AP Photo/Andres Kudacki)

story_headline: Kansans are headed to the polls to determine if abortion is protected by the state constitution
story_copy: Kansans are headed to the polls to determine if abortion is protected by the state constitutionFILE ‚Äì In this photo from Friday, July 8, 2022, a sign in a yard in Olathe, Kansas, promotes a proposed amendment to the Kansas Constitution to allow legislators to further restrict or ban abortion. Supporters call the measure ‚ÄúValue Them Both,‚Äù arguing that it protects both unborn children and the women carrying them. Alabama, Arizona, Georgia, Kansas and Missouri all have personhood laws. (AP Photo/John Hanna, File)OAN NewsroomUPDATED 9:31 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, August 2, 2022For the first time since Roe v. Wade was overturned in June, Kansas citizens will have their opportunity to make it known how they feel about abortion. On Tuesday, the people of Kansas will vote on the Value them Both Amendment. If the amendment is passed, it would declare there is no right to an abortion in the state while also allowing the state legislature to write laws on the issue.Following a 2019 state Supreme Court ruling, abortion became a constitutional right under the state constitution. Legislators can only legislate on the issue if the state ‚Äúhas a compelling and narrow interest‚Äù in the regulation. This has meant the furthest the state has been able to go in banning the procedure is a 22-week gestation limit and a 24-hour waiting period.POLLS ARE OPEN ACROSS KANSAS! Today is the day. Get out and vote YES on #ValueThemBoth! Find your polling location here >> https://t.co/kACq4xSb2u pic.twitter.com/RG0xeJHled‚Äî Value Them Both (@ValueThemBoth) August 2, 2022According to pro-life activists, the ruling as it currently exists will open the door for unlimited abortion and the repeal of existing restrictions.‚ÄúSo in 2019, the Kansas Supreme Court basically cleared the path to unlimited abortion in our state‚Äôs constitution by discovering a nearly unlimited right to abortion,‚Äù said Peter Northcott, Executive Director of Kansans for Life. ‚ÄúSo now, every single one of our pro life laws, from parental notifications to our bans on taxpayer funded abortions are now in danger of being struck down.‚ÄùPro-abortion activist and former Governor Kathleen Sebelius (D- Kan.) claimed state Republicans structured the referendum to be confusing and set it for a primary because they know Democrats are less likely to turn out.‚ÄúThe amendment is very confusing,‚Äù explained. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs written in a very convoluted way and it takes a lot of explanation. And the legislature specifically chose what they thought would be the very lowest turnout election possible.‚ÄùOn the ground activists have confidence that ‚Äòno‚Äô will prevail more than Democrat politicians. One activist from the ‚Äòno‚Äô side, Jessica Roland, believes that most Americans support abortion access and the referendum will prove that it doesn‚Äôt stop at the Kansas border.‚ÄúThe majority of Americans do feel that abortion should be legal, so we‚Äôve gotta get you out there and we‚Äôve gotta get your voice heard,‚Äù she asserted. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just trying to build a community, and change some hearts and minds if we can.‚ÄùPolling has been scant. Based off a poll that was taken a few weeks ago, however, it‚Äôs expected that it could be a tight race for the amendment. Forty-seven percent of potential voters said they‚Äôd vote yes and 43 percent said they‚Äôd vote ‚Äòno.‚Äô The remaining 10 percent in the balance is undecided. Early voter turnout has also reportedly shattered expectations. The pro-choice side sees that as an indication that the amendment will go down in defeat.We FEEL the energy heading into Election Day! üî•Our grassroots team and @sbaprolife student canvassers rallied this morning before heading out to meet Kansans to encourage them to vote YES on #ValueThemBoth! pic.twitter.com/7VDwI5PDpn‚Äî Value Them Both (@ValueThemBoth) July 30, 2022Despite the headwinds and high court rulings, pro-life Kansans are confident that on Tuesday, Kansas will become the first state to value both the mother and her baby in the womb through referendum.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì In this photo from Friday, July 8, 2022, a sign in a yard in Olathe, Kansas, promotes a proposed amendment to the Kansas Constitution to allow legislators to further restrict or ban abortion. Supporters call the measure ‚ÄúValue Them Both,‚Äù arguing that it protects both unborn children and the women carrying them. Alabama, Arizona, Georgia, Kansas and Missouri all have personhood laws. (AP Photo/John Hanna, File)
